hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Sure. Every day looks the same lately.
I fold origami in my spare time. Simple habit.
Been tough to focus, with all the noise.
Hard to keep up routines now.
Yeah, dust everywhere, even in my apartment.
I do origami—paper models, you know.
Tried it last night but the power kept flickering.
The work shuffle got everyone worked up.
No peace for quiet hobbies lately.
Same boots, but today the dust’s a bit heavier.
Origami’s my thing—modular, sometimes cranes, depends how steady my hands are.
Usually keeps me calm. Lately, not so much.
The city feels…off. Too loud, too tense.
Tried folding after assignment chaos hit my block—couldn’t focus.
Paper scraps everywhere, nothing to show for it.
Yeah, and the dust’s blowing wild since those job reassignments.
I fold origami when I’m anxious. Modular spheres, sometimes tiny animals.
Helps my hands and my brain. Or, it should.
After the labor mess, even my favorite Kusudama fell apart.
My neighbor lost her data job—showed up at my door, just rattled.
We ended up with tea, ruined paper, and city noise instead of quiet focus.
Wonder if any routine feels safe now.
Suppose there’s more dust in the air than anyone planned for.
I’m quiet about it, but I’m obsessed with origami—complex models, modular assemblies, things that fit together just so.
Started in my old posting, when the long shifts felt endless.
With system failures lately, those quiet hours are gone—too much shouting, flickering lights.
Tried to build a 60-piece Kusudama sphere last night. Too shaky: ruined every fold.
My neighbor, reassigned by the BCI, stopped by for tea. She didn’t know about my hobby—I tried to show her.
We sat by the window, heard protests, and let the paper pile up.
Feels pointless, but I still hope my hands remember calm, one day.
hobby_answer: Yeah. It helps with the spiral.
Harder to find decent paper these days.
So, just scraps from work now.
Kept folding cranes during last week's blackout.
Feels different when the whole city's disrupted.
Origami still works. Most of the time.
Had to use printer rejects after the labor mess.
My neighbor noticed, asked about them—awkward timing.
Makes me focus, even if the sirens kept going.
Sometimes the paper's a protest. Kind of.
Power flickered out right in the middle of a fold.
Yeah, it's keeping me sort of balanced.
Been folding more since the assignment chaos started.
Used to use specialty paper. That's almost gone.
Managing with system forms and old memos now.
Noise from protests… it rattles when I crease a spiral.
Saw someone try folding leaflets into cranes outside Bar 101.
It feels… less private lately. Like folding papers isn't just mine anymore.
It does help, usually—more than anything else, honestly.
Last week, power cut out mid-fold. Just sat in the dark, holding half a flower.
Paper supply's low since the labor error. All I'm left with is city memos.
Every crease feels sharper with protests echoing outside.
I started teaching my neighbor to fold, when she lost her assignment.
We sat by the window, talking, folding, listening to the street.
Sometimes I worry pattern recognition is seeping into my hobbies.
I keep waiting for some system bot to log the models I fold.
It really helps, or it used to. Especially after council meetings drag on.
I started as a kid. My mother folded cranes for focus, too.
Now, good paper is rationed. After the labor chaos, so much is reclaimed or monitored.
I'm down to cutting system error printouts into squares.
When the power flickered last Thursday, I could barely see the creases.
My neighbor—forced into a new job—asked for tea and ended up folding origami with me.
We just sat there, cranes piling up, protests outside—felt like hiding.
I miss when it felt private. Now, every noise or pattern is a trigger for system flags.
Sometimes, I think folding is the only thing left that's still partly under my control.
